title: take a breather harry make move back home
story: It is surely not too late for them to do a big, fat U-turn, especially when you see what their star power can achieve. It seems like such a waste for them to walk away.This week, Harry launched his Invictus Games with suitably stirring music and a passionate voiceover that showed how much he cares about this terric project, which helps wounded servicemen and women from all over the world.It is such a positive and effective way to give these heroes real purpose. Harry has been the driving force since it was little more than an idea on the back of a fag packet.The next day she made a low-key visit to young girls campaigning to combat climate change.Meghan was relaxed, caring and didn’t look for special treatment.Her visits were without pomp and fuss. You can tell it meant the world to everyone she encountered.She could easily have stayed in her mansion on Vancouver Island, closed the curtains and spent her days being pampered.Instead, she got up off her bottom and tried to do a bit of good for causes she cares about.It is admirable — but would the world have been as interestedthey were just plain old Harry and Meghan, without the aura of royalty And will the world’s Press still give such deserving causes the same level of attention this time next yearHarry and Meghan are no longer members of the Firm I’m not so sure. That’s why I would love them to slam on the brakes and reconsider their position.They can always rehire the staff axed from Frogmore House, especially as a move to Canada as “quasi royals” doesn’t look as welcoming as they first thought.Bedazzled PM Justin Trudeau at first promised that the famed Mounties would provide security and protection, but he has had to embarrassingly roll back on his offer and, while the extremely polite Canadians are happy to have Harry and Meghan as guests, they aren’t so keen on footing the bill to have them there permanently.The Queen would be thrilled to have her grandson back and the chance to get to know her great-grandson Archie properly.She would want to buy him his first pony and watch him learn to ride. He could grow up with his cousins George, Charlotte and Louis and be a proper part of the family.There are obviously tensions, hurt feelings and resentments within this clan. But surely the terribly British passive-aggressive arguments and niggles could be ironed out.It can’t really be too late to wipe the slate clean and start afresh.The first thing to be done is for Harry and Meghan to drop that daft court case against a British newspaper which printed a letter she had written to her dad, after he ­voluntarily handed it over.No one is going to come out of that fight with any dignity, and we don’t want to see Thomas Markle forced to give evidence against his daughter in court. They should concentrate their energies instead on trying to salvage their relationship, though I fear that ship has sailed.And brothers William and Harry need to go for a beer and sort out their gripes.Harry also needs to get back in touch with his old pals, who have been fiercely loyal and deeply hurt at being airbrushed out of his le.Surely an agreement can be hammered out which sees Harry and Meghan able to pursue their own causes without being stled by the Palace hierarchy, but also with everyone singing from the same song sheet and not constantly upstaging each other.I know the Queen wants Harry and Meghan’s new roles to be cut and dried as quickly as possible, with minimum fuss. But maybe what is needed is a bit of breathing space. Harry is due to go back to Canada in a couple of days to be reunited with Meghan and their young son.It might be a forlorn hope, but I would dearly like to see them having a rethink about their future and come back in from the Canadian cold.It would be a shamepride and stubbornness on both sides stopped them as I believe they would still get a warm welcome from the vast majority of us. It’s not too late.CAN we all just take a minute to salute the absolute force of nature that is Sun Online columnist and BBC presenter Deborah James Deborah has just been declared cancer-free – three years after a diagnosis of incurable bowel cancer and being given an EIGHT per cent chance of survival.Deborah is a walking miracle who has rewritten the textbooks and is giving hope to others living with the disease.She is also one of the kindest, sunniest, most decent women I know.She co-hosts the unmissable podcast You, Me And The Big C and is a regular on my TV show, where her funny, honest appearances have saved lives.Deborah takes every chance to spell out the symptoms of bowel cancer and encourage people not to be embarrassed about seeing a doctorthey notice any changes in their bowel movements.She has even laughingly nicknamed herself “Bowel Babe” to sht the silly stigma Brits feel about bums.As a result, people have had cancer detected early enough to get effective treatment, extending their lives.Sadly, Deborah’s heady news does not mean she is cured.This disease can rear its ugly head again, as Deborah knows all too well.But I hope she spends this weekend celebrating with friends, family and a large glass of wine, or by buying herself a sassy outfit and handbag.She’s a true inspiration. I’m proud to know her.She lost st after realising she was too heavy and wanted to be healthier for her son.Being overweight subjects you to all kinds of health problems. It is not about fat-shaming.You need to be sensible and take care of yourself.Adele has grafted to provide for her child and now has literally worked her ar*e off to make sure she is around for as long as possible. Good on her.THE new James Bond film is still a long way off, but speculation about who will succeed pouty Daniel Craig as  is reaching fever pitch.It seems that any cute actor to ever wear a tuxedo could be up for the part. My favourites for the role include Britain’s most handsome man Idris Elba, right – obviously – as well as Scotsman Richard Madden and the delectable Andrew Scott.Andrew was a villain in Bond’s previous big-screen outing, ’s Spectre, but let’s not hold that against him.If EastEnders’ Ben Mitchell can have SIX dferent heads over the years, we can surely ignore the slight inconvenience of Andrew’s scheming tech-terrorist trying to bump off all of MI.James Norton is another contender, but I have taken issue with him since catching up with The Trial Of Christine Keeler on BBC.It’s a slightly schlocky take on the infamous Sixties scandal involving the Tory cabinet minister John Profumo, who had a sexual relationship with Christine when she was just  – at the same time that she was “romantically linked” with Russian spy Yevgeny Ivanov.James plays society osteopath Stephen Ward, who acted as a sort of posh pimp and introduced Christine to Profumo in the first place. He is super-creepy in the series, with an intensely irritating habit of calling Christine “little baby” in almost every sentence.If you watch the show and sink a drink every time he utters those annoying words, you will be sloshed about ten minutes into each episode.It has taken the shine off Mr Norton for me, so I’m afraid he has to go to the back of the Bond queue.I AM convinced that when The Masked Singer’s Octopus character takes off its head, it will be revealed as model actress singer Caprice.I have absolutely no insider knowledge and only say this because Caprice actually released a single in the late Nineties.While doing the promotion rounds, on GMTV she very gamely warbled her song on a freezing beach while wearing not very much – in one of that show’s many fabulously surreal segments.If Caprice could cope with all that, then dressing up as a giant, eight-tentacled creature that can squirt black ink from its bottom would be a breeze.HUGH GRANT, who was absolutely brilliant in Paddington , is entitled to his opinion, like everyone . But I take real issue with him perpetuating the myth that tragic Princess Diana was “effectively killed” by British tabloid newspapers.Diana died in an accident because she was being driven by a drunk and didn’t have her seatbelt fastened. She had been stripped of her HRH title, which meant she didn’t have proper security, while the car was being driven too fast in a bid to elude bottom-feeding French paparazzi.To say the British Press were purely to blame is outrageous. And as Hugh Grant’s accusation went unchallenged during his appearance on US TV, most Americans will take it as gospel.They tend to believe posh actors who speak with cut-glass, upper-class accents.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: prince philip played by idris elba bbc
story: I genuinely believed that it was the gateto all we hold dear, and that it alone forced ITV and Channel  to make quality programmes. They had tothey wanted any viewers at all.Without Auntie, I reckoned that naked commercialism would take over and, soon, we’d end up with television like they had in Italy or Spain.Hours of incomprehensible game shows followed by a shouty weathergirl in not much of a bikini.But then along came Volvo sponsors Sky Atlantic with a host of dramas in which a Swedish detective in a jumper would solve crimes by staring into a lake for six weeks. We loved them.And then there was Amazon and Netflix, who realised thatwe were going to give them our money, they’d better bloody well give us some brilliant, intelligent shows in . So they did.All of this meant thatwe had the cash, we could get home after work and watch Breaking Bad or Ray Donovan or Dexter, or The Man In The High Castle or The Last Ship, or Ozark, or a Swedish woman staring into another lake, or Game Of Thrones, or The Sopranos or The Wire or  or ­Billions, or True Detective.Or we could watch a skateboarding duck on The One Show.Then there’s football. Right now,you’re a fan, you must pay BT, Sky and Amazon to stay in touch.That’s expensive, especially as you are also forced to pay your licence fee for a service that offers almost no live football at all. Or decent sport of any kind.To fight back against the onslaught of choice, the BBC has announced that by  . . . ready . . . drum roll . . . two-thirds of its staff will be based outside London.So what  Sure, you can have a technology hub in Newcastle and locate your Sounds app in Salford butall the decisions are still being made in Islington, over a plate of nuclear-free, vegetarian peace kale, it won’t make any dference.The fact is that the BBC is effectively governed by the monoculture that is social media. It’s ­terried of offending Twitter, so it abides by the rules.Far-right politics are bad. Far-left politics are fine. Veganism is good. Donald Trump is not.You get the impression thatthe BBC made The Crown, the Queen would be played by that guy in a wheelchair from Countryfile and Prince Philip by Idris Elba.And all they’d ever talk about, because all anyone ever talks about on any BBC show, is bloody climate change.I know it’s very noble but after a while, it becomes wearing. And I find myself sitting there ­thinking: “Oh for God’s sake, can’t they just have sex ”No. Obviously, no one can have sex on the BBC because a baby might result. And babies need food which, of course, causes global warming.The BBC was set up to “inform, educate and entertain”. Not “lecture, bombard and lecture again”.It’s got to the point now where the only BBC programmes I regularly watch are Pointless and Match Of The Day.I can’t even bring myself to listen to Attenborough any more. In the past, it was: “Look at this amazing fish which can breathe through its anus.”Now, it is: “Look at this amazing fish that can breathe through its anus and which is threatened by climate change.”Soon, it’s entirely possible the licence fee will become voluntary and when it does, the BBC will quickly learn that to ­survive it must make shows people want to watch.That’s people everywhere, not just ­Twitter people in a Shoreditch juice bar.Killing Eve. Fleabag. Earth’s Tropical Islands. More of that.And less of everything .So it’s good to see Meghan’s still working hard on behalf of those with mental-health issues.I’LL be honest. When it seemed likely that Mr Corbyn would win the General Election, I briefly entertained the idea of emigrating.I figured that there’d be no point living in the UKthe Government was going to take all my earnings and savings in tax.I even went so far as to go online and look at properties for sale in Italy. They all looked lovely – old stone farmhouses with pools – and all for less than a one-bedroom flat in Harpenden.But then I started to think: “Hang on. I don’t have any friends or family in Italy, so in about two hours I’d be lonely.”Then, the next day I’d drown my loneliness with a lunchtime drink, and then another.I’d make a rule that there’d be no drinking before , but soon I’d make that am.And within a month, I’d be pouring red wine on my cornflakes. Within a year, I’d be in a hospital trying to say, in Italian, to a doctor: “Please can I have a new liver ”I’m telling you all this because Harry and Meghan probably think le will be peachy by the sea in Canada.But home is where your friends are.And Harry’s friends, at least, are in the UK. He’s going to miss them. A lot. I guarantee it.WE have learned from American news footage that when there’s a small flood or some wind, we must go on the news and wail like stuck pigs about the injustice of it all.It makes me so angry that even my hair starts to itch.So I was delighted this week to see that when some floods came to the area where Jodie Kidd lives, she simply rolled up her trousers and carried on as normal.It does help, mind you, that she’s taller than The Shard.FOR reasons known only to a lunatic, it would cost £, to ring the bell in Big Ben to celebrate our departure from the EU.Hmmm. Seeing as the tower is currently hidden behind a million tons of scaffolding, why doesn’t someone go up there with a CD player and some big speakers We’d never know.THERE was further proof this week that the stock market is mad and everyone involved with it is Wolf Of Wall Street bonkers.Because apparently, City types now give Tesla a higher valuation than Ford and General Motors combined.Even though the electric minnow takes three months to produce what the big boys produce in a week.And is run by a dope enthusiast who calls random strangers “pedos” on social media. And gets away with it.A FRIEND of mine was driving along a dual carriageway this week when his super-green hybrid BMW i decided to have an electric duck fit.The power steering and power brakes both failed and it was only by using Herculean force he was able to coast, eventually, to a halt on the grass verge.He tells me that BMW hopes to have the car back to him very soon.But he’s not sure he wants it. He reckons he’d be better off with the petrol-powered M they’ve lent him in the meantime. Can’t say I blame him, really.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: great brexit blockage removed nation heal
story: The  referendum result will be delivered on and we will leave the European Union.Boris Johnson’s election ­victory has been the political equivalent of Dyno-Rod unblocking the drains of ­Westminster.In , our politics began to smell aseverything was stuck and nothing was moving.But the arrival of a majority government has changed all that. Not only is Brexit now sailing through Parliament, the Northern Ireland Assembly is back up and running after years in abeyance.Number  is now keen to get on with delivery.Ministers and advisers have been personally reminded that running their departments is far more important than appearing on television or ­talking to the media.Boris wants to restore the kind of Cabinet discipline we haven’t seen since the early Blair years. But moving forward also offers a chance to BRING THE COUNTRY BACK TOGETHER.As Boris’s great hero Winston Churchill used to say: “In ­victory, magnanimity.”At Prime Minister’s Questions this week, he took a much less confrontational style than usual.With everyone apart from the Labour and Scottish National Party leaders, he went out of his way to be generous and not score party-political points.Given that Boris likes to be liked, this is a more natural approach for him than being confrontational with every opposition MP.Boris wants to occupy the common ground. His approach to Brexit night on January  reflects that.Rather than being out with Nigel Farage and Co in Parliament Square, he will address the nation on this momentous moment from Downing Street.I am told the message will be upbeat but he will also try to reach out and reassure those who voted Remain. It would be tempting for Boris to join in some full New Year’s Eve-style celebration. And there are undoubtedly Leave voters who would love him to do just that.The danger is that this might alienate those who voted Remain but who have now reconciled themselves to the result and want to help the country pull together.What is key is that in the coming weeks, the Government shows it knows what it wants to do to improve voters’ lives. Boris must put meat on the bones of his plan to “level-up” infrastructure and opportunity across the country.He must show he knows not only how to keep the ­economy growing but how to get it out of second gear, which it has been stuck in — along with most of the West — since the financial crisis of .The next few months present a remarkable opportunity for the PM. He has a sizeable ­parliamentary majority and a united government, while both Labour and the Lib Dems are absorbed by their own leadership contests.This is his moment to really crack on.THIS week, the European Union Trade Commissioner Phil Hogan said it is “just not possible” to conclude everything on the UK’s future relationship with the EU by the December  deadline for the end of the transition period.But the UK and the EU both agreed to that timeframe in the political declaration.The EU shouldn’t have signed up to itthey didn’t think it was possible to agree things by that date.Boris Johnson is determined not to extend this transition period.He feels the whole process has gone on too long already. So there needs to be some compromise to keep things moving.What is key is that at the end of this year the UK is no longer sending millions to the EU every day the UK determines its own immigration policy and the role of the European Court of Justice in the UK ends on all matters other than the rights of EU citizens.THE Royal Family is in its worst crisis since the death of Diana.By contrast, Boris Johnson is determined to stay out of the current drama.BORIS JOHNSON’S refusal of Nicola ­Sturgeon’s demands for a second Scottish independence ­referendum was definitive.But it will become very hard to ­continue to refuse those callsthe SNP wins a majority at next year’s Scottish Parliament elections, in a campaign dominated by the ­question of whether or not there should be a second referendum.On a list of things that could derail this Government, Scotland is very high up the list.The best way to stop that happening is for the Tories, along with the other unionist parties, to deny the SNP an absolute majority at Holyrood in .That will require the Government to pay more attention to ­Scotland and be more prepared to call out the SNP on its ­domestic policy failures.THE first public hustings of the Labour leadership contest take place today – and the race looks set to be hard fought.A survey this week putting Shadow ­Business Secretary Rebecca Long Bailey ­narrowly ahead has dented the idea that Shadow Brexit ­Secretary Keir Starmer has it in the bag. It doesn’t look like the contest is going to be a particularly comradely affair.The personal jabs are already coming and the election isn’t over until April. Starmer and Long Bailey are the two front- runners. The Tories believe both candidates provide them with opportunities.Long Bailey wants to continue the Corbyn project. She will not bring Labour back towards the mainstream of British politics. Starmer, though, is the architect of the parliamentary manoeuvring on Brexit and the second ­referendum policy that hurt Labour so badly in those Red Wall constituencies lost in the election.As one Tory grandee puts it: “If they go for Keir, they’re locking in a problem with those Leave-voting seats.”The dark horse is Lisa Nandy. She performed best in the hustings for Labour MPs, put in a far better performance with interviewer Andrew Neil than Jeremy Corbyn did and is picking up some interesting endorsements.The longer this contest goes on, the better she will do. But even Nandy is making missteps and ­providing the Tories with ammunition in the event she becomes leader.This week, she defended free movement. She claimed voters in towns of the North and Midlands weren’t really opposed to it.This flies in the face of the fact that so many of these places voted Leave in , then flipped to the Tories in last month’s “Brexit election”.Nandy won’t pay an immediate price for this misstep, as most Labour members are pro-free movement themselves.But her decision to speak out shows how focused the contest is on Labour’s “selectorate” and not the broader electorate.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ambulance frontline made me 99 casualty
story: He was signed off with PTSD after being called out to a two-year-old girl who had been physically abused and later died.When Dan ed to work he campaigned for better mental health support for ambulance staff.He won an NHS Heroes Award after setting up the Our Blue Light campaign.Now he has written a book lting the lid on the le of an ambulance worker. Here, we reveal some exclusive extracts.PEOPLE always ask me about the weirdest injuries I’ve seen.Well, I once went out to a man who claimed he had “snapped his k**b”.We whisked him off to hospital. I’m taking his word for it. I wasn’t going to start inspecting it.I’ve also been out to a fair few snapped banjo strings — or, more correctly, frenulums — which are the small tags of skin between the foreskin and the shaft of a penis.One minute someone is making sweet love, the next the sheets are covered in claret.We tell the patient to wrap their old chap in a tea towel and hop on the ambulance.You wouldn’t believe some of the nonsense we get sent to.I’ve heard of someone wanting an ambulance to be sent to resuscitate a dead pigeon, help find someone’s trousers, deal with a hedgehog in a garden, treat someone whose feet were bleeding from wearing new shoes and fix a dislodgedfinger nail.ONE Sunday afternoon, we get a call to a carvery restaurant. Our screen simply said: Male choking.When we swing the doors open, the waft of carvery — old, sweaty veg and cheap lager — almost knocks us backwards.Down his throat I can see a big piece of steak. I pull out my mini-Hoover and suck out the gravy, before pulling out my special forceps and fishing out the offending item.We ventilate the patient and a couple of minutes later he’s sat up talking. As we’re pushing him towards the exit, the whole restaurant erupts into cheering and clapping. I feel like an actor leaving the stage after a triumphant opening night.I COULDN’T tell you how many people I’ve seen dead on a toilet.It wasn’t just Elvis Presley who breathed his last on the throne. It’s so common, we call it the “death poo”.We went to one woman in a care home who died mid-evacuation. The family were on their way, so me and my partner lugged the woman over to the bed and tucked her in, so she looked nice and peaceful.SEEING my first dead body is etched on my mind. I thought people died with their eyes shut, but this guy is staring straight at the ceiling.I’m stood there thinking, “What happens next ”, when my partner does something humbling: He closes the man’s eyes.Back downstairs, my partner breaks the bad news to the dead man’s we: “Your husband has passed away in his sleep. He wouldn’t have known anything about it.”An ambulance person’s job isn’t just to treat the injured and sick. It is also to bring calm and dignity and counsel the bereaved.A MESSAGE comes though: Seven-week-old child, not breathing. cardiac arrest.I switch on the blue lights and floor it. We can only drive an ambulance mph over the limit, and it’s not a rule that’s usually flouted. But this particular job is a case of b******s to the rules.The baby is seven-weeks-old. It is white, floppy and bleeding from the nose.From arriving at the house to arriving at the hospital takes no more than three minutes.The dad had fallen asleep on his bed next to the baby, rolled over and suffocated it. The mum had been out with friends for the first time since her baby was born.After an hour of treatment, the decision is made to cease CPR. The mum screams again, “No! You can’t stop!” But the baby is dead. There is nothing more we can do.In my  years on the frontline, I’ve seen so many lives lost, but so many lives saved.THERE is a superstition in the ambulance service thatanyone says the word “quiet”, the s**t will ­suddenly hit the fan. So we call it “the Q word”, just as actors refer to Macbeth as “the Scottish play”.But there must have been a lot of ambulance workers forgetting ­themselves of late, because the s**t’s hitting the fan every day.Suffice to say that the state of the ambulance service scares me.When that ambulance arrives, I guarantee you will get the best treatment possible.But will it arrive too late  When I started there was a snooker table in the ambulance ­station.Now the calls wait for us and we don’t have time to go to the toilet, let alone make sure our ambulances are ship-shape.It’s not uncommon to be on a job, open a bag and discover something is missing.A JOB comes on our screen: Child fallen over in shower. Unconscious. I try the door and it’s locked. Suddenly, we hear the thud, thud, thud of big feet thundering down stairs. The door swings open to reveal a burly lad with a limp child in his arms.He says, “There you go, mate”, and shoves the child into my chest, asshe is nothing more precious than a pile of dirty washing. I can tell immediately that the girl, who is about two-years-old, has horrendous injuries.Her face is black and blue, as are her legs. Her eyes are half-closed, her pupils dilated and her breathing is noisy and slow. I hand the patient to my crewmate Paul, who can feel her body clicking, which suggests she also has broken bones. We both know something is seriously amiss, but we can’t say that.The doctors agree with us that the girl’s injuries are non-accidental. A short while later, the man is arrested. At home, I can’t shake the image of the little girl in my arms, covered in bruises, wheezing and gasping for breath. Several days later I heard that the girl had died and the man had been charged with murder.This pushed me further towards breaking point. I became more withdrawn at work. I stopped playing with my kids. I started drinking heavily to combat my anxiety and help me sleep. My doctor was so understanding and supportive. She signed me off work and referred me for counselling.The man changed his plea to guilty of manslaughter. The Crown Prosecution Service accepted he’d lost his temper and violently shaken her. He was sentenced to nine years in prison. It felt like this guy had got away with murder.IT wasn’t until I was diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder PTSD that I realised I was vulnerable — and that everyone was. I wrote and posted the first of many blogs, detailing my crash and subsequent road to recovery.I’d been back on the job for a few weeks when my blogs went viral, which was a bit embarrassing. But those blogs, and the responses to them, changed my le forever.Ambulance workers from all over the country sent me emails, thanking me for sharing my story.A COUPLE of months after ing to work, I’m in the ambulance with Paul and a job appears on our screen: Female Bleeding PV .Sprawled in the bath is a woman. There is blood everywhere. My initial thought is that it could be a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. Or maybe it’s a miscarriage.But when I ask the guythere was a risk of pregnancy, he replies that there wasn’t. During his examination, the consultant has discovered a severed umbilical cord and delivered a nearly full-term placenta.Later, I learn that the police did find a baby, in a plastic bag in the hallway. Sadly, it was already dead. I didn’t really discuss the job with Paul.He seemed happy just plodding along and I took that to mean he was a stronger person than me. One evening I received a phone call from my manager.The whole time I’d been pouring my heart and soul into raising awareness of mental illness in the ambulance service, my mate had been sinking into an abyss.I’M tremendously proud to say I work for the service and I have a deep love for the job. It might not be the sexiest occupation, but it’s one of the most rewarding.How many people can say they arrived home late from work or missed their child’s sports day because they were saving someone’s le It’s a tough gig, but someone has to do it. And I’m glad it’s me. I feel like the luckiest man in the world.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris unifying speech outside no10
story: He is walking a tightrope between jubilant Leavers and disconsolate Remoaners . . . with most of the population somewhere between.So a unying speech outside No at pm is a must. A laser display, countdown clock and a mass of Union flags all sound good.Big Ben’s bongs were scuppered by Commons authorities. So why not get the BBC to play them at that pivotal moment  And Leavers wanting the full party can still join Nigel Farage in ­Parliament Square.We note the EU’s Guy Verhofstadt cheering himself up with the fantasy of us rejoining one day. Sorry, Guy.Our economy will now have global opportunities. His is forever crippled by the euro. No government will shackle us to that.As for millions of UK-based EU citizens whose rights he is worried about, our system is simple, free and now working well.It’s high time Brussels strong-armed all its members into being equally generous to OUR expats.So far, disgracefully, they have not.IF Harry and Meghan have now moved away for good we wish them the best.So long as they relinquish their titles, all handouts from the Duchy of Cornwall and Sovereign Grant, and refund £.million the public lavished on the house they abandoned in nine months.We are sorry Meghan found her “soul crushed” by Royal le so soon after she enthusiastically married into it.And that she found Britain insufficiently welcoming despite her joyous national celebration of a wedding, for which the public happily paid £million and to which a besotted Press devoted entire editions.It is oddHarry failed to warn her what she might expect, but there we are.Happy mansion hunting, Mr and Mrs Wales!HE may not be a household name, but we salute actor Laurence Fox.It takes guts to defy the suffocating liberal-left or Corbynite consensus in the arts and admit you’re of the centre right. Maybe others will now join him in coming out of the political closet.It cannot be lost on them — with Brexit, the Tories’ huge majority, Ricky Gervais exposing Hollywood hypocrisy and the public anger at the Waleses — that years of hysterical, “woke” dominance of the national conversation looks like ending.It’s probably too much to hope that even the BBC is finally getting the message. title: schoolgirls tampons sanitary towels free
story: Ministers have vowed to give free period products to all girls at state schools and colleges in England.They say the move will means kids don’t miss class because they cannot afford tampons.Children’s minister Michelle Donelan said: “Periods are a normal part of everyday le and we do not want young people missing out on lessons because of them.“We know that it is not easy for everyone to access period products where and when they need them.“This scheme will deal with those problems so young people can go about their daily lives without getting caught outthey have come on their period unexpectedly, forgotten to bring products with them orthey can’t afford the products they need.”One in ten young women in the UK have been too poor to buy sanitary products, research carried out by the charity Plan UK in  found.Rose Caldwell, chief executive of Plan International UK, said: “We know that some girls miss school because they don’t have period products, and that they have had to use items like toilet roll and socks because they can’t afford anything .“So having access to a range of period products at school will make a very real dference to many girls’ lives.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boy vanished motorway dad nine hours
story: The boys dad, Umair Rahim, has told how he kept praying that his son Aadil would be found safe and well after he went missing at Newport Pagnell Services near Milton Keynes.The frantic dad said: I had every faith that the police would find him.My faith helped me through a very dficult time.He said that his we, who had stayed at home within their younger son, had feared the worst but he “never gave up hope.”The six-year-old had got lost and disorientated on Friday evening after going to the loo at a service station on the M.After being spotted by a helicopter nine hours later, the little lad, who only had a jumper to keep him warm, was reunited with his dad.More than , members of the public helped in the search for the schoolboy.Umair, , speaking exclusively to The Sun Online from his home in Nottingham said: “My boy was thankfully found safe.That’s all that matters. I never stopped hoping and police kept reassuring me they’d find him.He has no idea about all the fuss surrounding him.He had been wandering up and down the side of the motorway after going to the toilet and when he came out he couldn’t find the coach and he got lost from the rest group.Umair, who runs a used car dealership, told how the horror unfolded when he got a call from the police saying his son was missing.The pupil at a school in Nottingham had been on a coach trip to London to visit some off the sights and a museum.The group stopped for a break at Newport Pagnell Service Station near Milton Keynes, Bucks, before continuing with their -mile journey north to Nottingham.Umair said: “You hear of children going missing and never being found after many years like the girl Madeleine McCann.But with my son we knew he couldn’t have gone far and was hopefully still somewhere nearby.“At the time you don’t really know but I couldn’t let silly thoughts get inside my head.I had to stay strong and hopeful. He hadnt been snatched by anyone, he had wandered off and got lost.Thankfully he didn’t get onto the M, he remained at the side of the motorway.”Umair said that his relatives and close friends were relieved to hear the good news of the six-year-olds .Aadil, however, was busy playing with his brother before being told by his parents to “get some sleep.”He said: “I cannot thank the police and local community enough. They are lesavers.They were excellent. My boy is fine, he is comfortable.”His we added: “Our child is safe, we are blessed and so thankful to everyone who helped find him. It is such a relief.”Recounting what happened during the nine-hour search, he said: “I didn’t join the search party. I sat in the police car all night waiting and praying and hoping.There were helicopters searching, local people and police. The officers kept telling me: ‘We’ll find him, he can’t have gone far, we’ll find him for you.’“They were very reassuring and comforting. I was worried because it was so cold and he didn’t have thick clothing on and I thought he may be scared and tired and hungry.But the police made me feel better. Then suddenly he just appeared in front of me.A helicopter overhead had spotted him sitting near a big block beside some roadworks on the motorway after wandering up and down.”“It was about  am and he was with some officers and he just walked towards me, back to his father, asnothing really had happened and I gave him the biggest hug. I didn’t want to let him go.”The tearful dad added: “That was the best feeling. My boy was safe and well and not hurt.”After being found safe and sound, the six-year-old was given a thorough check at hospital and was told he was fine.Superintendent Amy Clements said this morning: This was a very dficult operation involving a very young boy and we are relieved to say that Aadil has been found safe and well.I’d like to take this opportunity to thank the local community, who immediately offered help in trying to find Aadil.Also Id like to thank those who have co-operated with Police during this time.This was a large operation in dficult conditions so Id like to also publicly thank the search and rescue teams who assisted in the search and the large number of officers involved, including the National Police Air Service which helped bring this positive resolution.We are so very glad that he has been found and are thankful to everyone involved in assisting with that.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris discussions us before eu
story: The PM wants Cabinet authorisation to open discussions during a visit to Washington next month, US diplomats have revealed.It comes after civil servants drew up advice for ministers on the pros and cons of making the move.One government source who has seen the advice said: “We mean business and we’re not messing around. The political signal would be, ‘We’ve got the capacity to do this at the same time, don’t hold this up’.”Mr Johnson is expected to visit Washington in the second or third week of February before US President Donald Trump sets off on his re-election campaign.He believes opening talks with the US first will avoid becoming trapped by Brussels negotiators like his predecessor Theresa May.It would also “negate some of the concerns of the EU trying to play the ball in the way they want”.The US was also said to be “impatient to get started” on talks.Under the time­frame being discussed by both sides, the Cabinet decision would be followed by the publication of UK trade negotiation objectives within two weeks. The US will have two two weeks to reply.Yesterday, the European Parliament’s Brexit co-ordinator Guy Verhofstadt boasted that he had secured a deal to stop the automatic deportation of EU citizens who missed the deadline to apply for settled status.But he admitted that Europe had failed to secure the same promise to British ex-pats.He said, after meeting Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay in London, that the Government had ­conceded on giving EU citizens a hard copy of their settled status ­confirmation.He said he was pressing  EU countries who had yet to make the same commitment for Brits.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: scottish hotel owner doesnt hire smelly smokers
story: Angela Wimbe says she does not have a single smoker on her staff at Heather Glen Guest House in Moray, Scotland and never has - because she doesnt feel comfortable with them.The businesswoman claims she can always tellsomeone has a nicotine habit as soon as they meet as she can smell it on their clothes.She said: I hate smoking. I can tell when I meet somebodytheyre a smoker.As soon as somebody walks in you can usually smell [it] on their clothes.I hate when people come into my premises stinking of smoke.Angela was wading into a row about whether non-smokers should be given extra time off to make up for colleagues cigarette breaks at the time.Posting on Facebook on Tuesday, she added: I dont really associate with any smokers and Ive no close friends that [...] are smokers because I just dont feel comfortable with people that smoke.I dont have any smokers working at the guest house and never have.As an employer,I had two equally matched candidates for a job but one was a smoker and the other not, I would give the job to the non-smoker.According to UK law, it is only illegal to discriminate against someone based on certain protected characteristics.These include age, sex, marital status, pregnancy, disability, race, religion, and sexual orientation - and not lestyle choices such as smoking or drinking.However Angela, who has owned Heather Glen Guest House for  years, has faced a discrimination backlash since her smoking rant on social media.Susan Davies said: Thats called discrimination, your a silly fool.And Nicola Evans wrote: Surely its then down to personality and whether you gel with the person Hitting back at critics, ex-lecturer Angela said: Everything is discrimination. Youve got to decide on something.If you look at somebody and you dont like their hair style, thats discrimination.If you dont like their voice when they talk and think I couldnt stand listening to that persons voice every day, thats discrimination.Im just saying it. Everyone shies away from it.I dont discriminate against race or colour or anything like that. That doesnt bother me at all.Butsomeone came in dirty, smelling of smoke or [with] dirty fingernails, you think I dont want this person coming into my business because its not a good look.Acas, an independent body that provides advice employment rights, claimed smoking should not have any bearing on whether or not to employ them.Acas senior advisor, John Palmer, added: “Employers should think about the impracticalities and risks of refusing to employ smokers.As well as being a potential infringement on a workers human rights and their right to private le,a non-smoker has been working somewhere for years and then becomes a smoker, it would likely be unfair to dismiss them on those grounds.It’s also unlikely to make good business sense – whether or not a worker chooses to smoke is usually going to have little to do with their qualications, experience and abilities.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lisa nandy labour mp
story: She is standing for leadership in the forthcoming Labour election. But what  do we know about her Lisa Nandy was born in August  in Manchester to mum Luise — the daughter of Liberal Lord Byers — and Marxist academic Dipak Nandy.She grew up in Bury, Gtr Manchester and studied Politics at Newcastle University.Ms Nandy worked in several charities before taking up a career in politics.She first served as a Labour councillor in Hammersmith and Fulham before she was selected for the Wigan constituency in the  General Election.Nandy was selected as the Labour parliamentary candidate for Wigan constituency in February  from an all-women shortlist.On May , , she was elected to parliament.She became the constituencys first female MP and one of the first Asian female MPs.She was appointed to the Education Select Committee in July  and was appointed Parliamentary Private Secretary to Tessa Jowell, the shadow Olympics minister, in October .Two years later she was made shadow childrens minister and, in October , she was appointed shadow charities minister.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe five candidates for Labour leader have clashed over anti-Semitism, Brexit and more in the first hustings of the contest. The wide-ranging -minute debate in Liverpool was the first of a string of events before nominations from local parties and affiliates close mid-February. Members will then vote for a winner declared on April . Rebecca Long-Bailey, Keir Starmer, Lisa Nandy, Jess Phillips and Emily Thornberry all pleaded for party unity as they stand to replace Jeremy Corbyn. But they clashed on key issues including the anti-Semitism crisis. Here are the  things we learned as they faced off.  Labour leadership candidates issued a plea for party unity.Left-wing candidate Rebecca Long-Bailey told the audience ided parties do not win elections. She said members must not call other members a cult or tell them to F- off and join the Tories. We have to be honest that over the last four years we havenapost been united, she added. Jess Phillips, a prominent critic of outgoing leader Jeremy Corbyn , said the name calling within the party has been horrendous and called for Labour to build a broad team.“Sometimes the membership felt they were not being included and in fact that’s been the case for a long time, she said. Emily Thornberry said Labour members should stop fighting each other and concentrate on fighting the Tories. We need to be in power. The country is crying out for an alternative government and it will not happen unless we are united, she said. Sir Keir Starmer agreed there had been too much ision, adding: We are unstoppable when we are united. Drawing repeatedly on his time as Director of Public Prosecutions he said: “Stop asking the question which bit of the party are you from and start asking - what are you saying. “If we can do it for an election campaign we can do it as a party. I’ve run an organisation where I’ve changed values and culture. You have to model it from the top.” . But they clashed fiercely on anti-Semitism  All five leadership candidates signed the Board of Deputies of British Jewsapos  pledges to deal with anti-Semitism. But the hustings was hit by a row after Jess Phillips took a furious swipe at rivalsapos alleged silence over the issue. The bookiesapos long-shot slammed fellow candidates who she accused of failing to speak up about the partyaposs crisis while they were in the shadow cabinet. Three rivals - Rebecca Long-Bailey, Emily Thornberry and Keir Starmer - are in Jeremy Corbynaposs top team. The fth candidate Lisa Nandy is a backbencher.The Labour Party needs a leader who has spoken out against anti-Semitism, and other forms of harassment in fact, when others were keeping quiet, she said.I donapost remember some of the people here being in that particular room or being in those particular fights. Emily Thornberry and Keir Starmer hit back at Ms Phillips - both insisting they spoke out about the problem. Ms Long-Bailey had already given her answer but has previously said the partyaposs response was not good enough. Ms Phillips also took a swipe at left-wing favourite Rebecca Long-Bailey - who recent polls suggest is in a two-horse race with Sir Keir Starmer. She said she was literally laughed at on the school run about Labouraposs broadband policy - overseen by Shadow Business Secretary Ms Long-Bailey. And she hit out at Ms Long-Baileyaposs plan to replace the Lords with an elected Senate based outside London. Ms Phillips said: Weaposve got to speak the language people speak on the doorstep. No one talks about federalism or wanting this Senate or that Senate. Weaposve got to start talking like people talk, about the things they actually talk about.Deputy leader candidate Richard Burgon declared I have not signed and won’t be signing the  pledges from the Board of Deputies on dealing with anti-Semitism. He said heaposs concerned about outsourcing our complaints procedure and claimed the approach could be marginalising black and LGBT Jewish voices. Fellow deputy candidate Dawn Butler has also not signed the  pledges. She said she wants to see the Equalities and Human Rights Commission report and deal with that first. I don’t want to rush this. It’s too important to rush it - we have to get it right, she said, to huge cheers. . They staked out their positions on Brexit The candidates also clashed on Brexit .Remainer and second referendum backer Ms Thornberry demanded a candidate who had frankly been on the right side all along, while Ms Phillips said Labour could not turn away from Europe. But Ms Nandy said nuance on Brexit had been “airbrushed” out of the debate. Remainer Sir Keir added: We can’t now let Brexit tear our party apart for the next  or  years.” . They all want to take on the media instead of aposwading through s***apos...  Candidates vowed to take on media coverage of Labour - with Sir Keir committing he would not be interviewed by The Sun newspaper. Ms Long-Bailey said she was a victim of smears over her position on abortion and would talk to fair journalists but not others. Ms Thornberry said: The Daily Mail have been employing people full time trying to cut me off at knees. I’ve had a whole van load of Sun journalists turn up at my house at one stage. I’m afraid I have a boring le, there’s nothing  they can do. Ms Thornberry added: Being leader of the Labour Party in opposition is, quite frankly, the worst job in the world.. we have to wade through an awful lot of s***. ... Which asked Jess Phillips to pose with bacon  Jess Phillips had perhaps the strangest interaction with the media so far - when someone asked her to recreate Ed Milibandaposs most famous moment. She revealed: I was asked to hold a bacon sandwich in a photo the other day. I refused.”  Keir Starmer -   Rebecca Long-Bailey -   Lisa Nandy -   Jess Phillips -   Emily Thornberry -   OUT: Clive LewisOdds Jan  from Ladbrokes. For full profiles and how the contest works click here. Deputy leadership candidates  Angela Rayner Richard Burgon Rosena Allin Khan Dawn Butler Ian Murray OUT: Khalid Mahmood The final question was what keeps candidates awake at night. And apart from the snoring of Rebecca Long-Baileyaposs husband, the answers were deadly serious.What keeps me awake at night is where this country is going, said Lisa Nandy. She lamented the “collapse of our public services” and the future of her young son: Everything is just so achingly heartbreakingly familiar. I do not want him to be  like I was before he sees his first Labour government. Rebecca Long-Bailey highlighted inequality and the climate crisis, while Ms Thornberry said Labour had to be a “fighting machine”. Keir Starmer said he was troubled by the “frustrations of opposition” adding: I’ve never known a time when we’ve so radically needed a Labour governmentAnd Jess Phillips revealed she was kept awake by an abuse victim who fled to a refuge turned to her before the election to say: I like that Boris Johnson .I think I’ll vote for him. . Jess Phillips and apostough old birdapos Emily Thornberry both think they have the personality to beat Boris Johnson Ms Phillips said she could give no reassurance to people until  now Boris Johnson has a majority - but insisted she was the big personality to take on the PM.Labour could not have “an intellectual argument when Tories are talking about bells, not NHS waiting times, she said. We’ve got to do something bold. And Boris Johnson would be terried to face me. Boris Johnson is scared of what he doesn’t understand, she added. He literally can’t understand what I’m saying sometimes. Ms Thornberry also claimed she had the tough old bird personality to face off against the Old Etonian PM. He is in the end a liar, he is callous, he doesn’t care, he plays at politics, he plays with people’s lives, she said. title: saira khan meghan markle fans
story: NewsopinionSaira Khan: Meghan Markle fans are right, Britain IS racist... but not like it wasOur columnist has experienced her fair share of racism, and explains how it might not be as blatant as in the s or s, but its just as viciousShareCommentsBySaira Khan:,  JAN NewsopinionMeghan and Harry " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailWhile Meghan and Harry are typing in “Canada” and “no maximum rooms” on estate agent websites, we’re left searching for the real reason they are leaving us. And racism is the prime suspect. The Royal Family couldn’t get more white and there is no doubt Meghan had some horrible racist stuff thrown her way. Harry spoke of the racial undertones and “outright racism” on social media and online article comments. All that talk of her “exotic DNA” and chimp photos. Many royalists seem to think Meghan should be grateful she was allowed to join in the first place. I have had to deal with my share of racism. I know I’ve had to work harder than others to get the same rewards. But I refused to be a victim. I was born in the s and grew up in the s and s. Racism was in your face – it was acceptable to call me a “p***” to my face, even at work. But I didn’t quit, run away and just drop my responsibilities. I had bills to pay. The best way to deal with ­ignorant people is to stick it out, not run, show them your ability and change their opinion. But it is hard. I also have to accept that as a woman of colour, someone may not like me because I’m a woman and opinionated. Nothing to do with the colour of my skin. Not all Meghan’s critics are racist. If Harry’s new we had been a Kate clone, but had dared to be dferent in other ways, she would be stirring up a hornet’s nest too. But I have been called a racist for daring to say this might not be a race issue. I’ve been labelled “flaky” and “naive” and I am saying it to keep my “white masters happy”. That because I’m not black, I cannot understand what a mixed- race woman like Meghan would be going through. Really  I’d call that racist. And firing back that because someone is “white and privileged” they don’t get it, well that’s racist too.  That’s what happened to actor Laurence Fox on Question Time this week when he waded into the Sussex debate. He claims we are the most “tolerant, lovely country” in Europe. But I say this generation is facing a dferent kind of prejudice – more subtle than when I grew up. It’s called microaggression and it has crept into our lives and conversations – everyday offensive comments directed at a minority group. I get it all the time. The “where are you really from ” awkward stuff.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA British rescuer has kept a harrowing diary of efforts to save animals amid Australia’s desperate bushfire crisis. Charity worker Georgie Dolphin joined teams scouring blackened woodland for injured, starving ­creatures to bring to safety. In one gruelling -hour day alone they found  koalas, a wallaby, a kangaroo and a possum and took them to an emergency centre. Georgie, , was spurred into ­action as the world watched in horror while the worst-ever bushfires Down Under killed at least  people and an estimated billion animals. The mum of one was particularly shocked by images of dead animals and torched properties on South Australia’s huge Kangaroo Island, which has been likened to Noah’s Ark for its unique range of wildle. It has been one of the worst ­affected areas and was the scene of a family tragedy when popular Dick Lang, , and his son Clayton, , died fleeing flames. Georgie, normally a Sydney-based campaign manager for the charity Humane Society International, put her le at risk to join relief efforts on the ground for the first time. She is spending two weeks on the island, on which huge plumes of smoke could be seen from space. Georgie, who grew up on a farm in Kintbury, Berks, said: “It’s rewarding but devastating. I know it’s dangerous here but I just had to help. “Those animals are waiting to die, their habitat has been destroyed and they have no food or water. Each creature brings a precious moment as they might be rehabilitated or, with severe injuries, humanely put down.” Georgie is working with disaster relief ­experts Adam Parascandola, Kelly Donithan and five other brave colleagues.  Here, she shares her log from last Thursday giving an insight into their incredible efforts..am We grab breakfast then collect rescue supplies – towels for catching and calming species, washing baskets to transport them, bungee cords to secure them safely in the basket, huge water bottles and tubs to build water stations and a walkie-talkie to keep in touch while scanning the area.am I drive us  minutes to a rescue hotspot our team has come to refer to as “hell” deep within the fire-ravaged plantations. The further we drive, the more devastation we ­witness. Sightings of charred wildle corpses are regular, and smouldering areas still smoking along the roadside remind us of the extent of this disaster. The smell of carcasses is unbearable..am We hit our first destination and navigate a dirt track, winding left and right to avoid the blackened animal bodies dotted along our path. Five minutes later we spot a koala on the ground next to a fallen tree branch in a desperate state. Kelly approaches the koala from behind with a towel. We transfer her to a washing basket carrier, secured with a bungee cord. .am Kelly spots a baby koala on the ground with no mum to be seen. She scoops her up with ease. The baby is completely lost, dazed and starving. .am Another young koala is spotted sitting alone on the forest floor. Kelly passes her to me to hold close. It is the highlight of my day. Another ­precious le saved with high hopes of a future back in the wild one day. She peeps up at me from under the towel with melt-your-heart brown eyes. I feel a duty for us to do all we can for her and her species.  .am Rescue efforts continue and we soon have six koalas plus one wallaby secured in baskets or towels. There’s very little vegetation but some surviving koalas can be spotted perched up trees. If we approach too quickly they are spooked and climb up higher, evading rescue. .am We head to Kangaroo Island Wildle Park where an ­animal triage centre has been set up. In the car we stay silent to ­minimise stress for our rescues. On ­arrival they are gently transferred into ­carriers, noted as HSI rescues, and await their turn for a full medical. There are dozens of staff here, flown in to respond to the huge emergency.pm Back on the trail we spot a ­kangaroo lying still on the ground and think she must be dead, then she tries to get up. We manage to contain her. She has very bad sores and ­injuries on her feet from burns. .pm We find another koala sitting out of reach in a tree in an alarmingly poor state clinging on to a tiny baby. Frustratingly unable to reach her, we note her location and set up a water station nearby, hoping that will help to give her a better chance, alleviating some suffering. We are using time-lapse cameras on the stations and it’s rewarding to see many koalas are accessing them in our absence.  .pm We find a final few casualties and by the end of the day our tally totals  rescues delivered to the Wildle Park. Sadly, the kangaroo could not be saved and had to be euthanised. But there is comfort in her s­uffering being over. Although we are exhausted we feel genuinely ­rewarded at being able to make a dference.

title: mum who bought house horrors
story: NewsMum who bought house of horrors says flowers wouldnt grow where bodies buriedEXCLUSIVE: The murders of Patricia and William Wycherley case are being dramatised in a Sky TV series starring Oscar winner Olivia Colman. Here, homeowner Sue Bramley tells how she had no clue of her home’s dark past - until the police came knockingShareCommentsByDan WarburtonMark Christy:,  JAN NewsSophie and Sue with the patio plant " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mum who bought a house where two murder victims were buried in the garden has told how no flowers would grow over the spot where the bodies lay. For seven years Sue Bramley remained unaware of her home’s dark past and was baffled as all her bedding plants, lawn seed and turf died. Eventually she installed a patio, where she and her family would sunbathe and enjoy barbecues together. Then police searching for previous owners Patricia and William Wycherley, both missing, arrived to dig up the slabs. And they unearthed the couple’s corpses in a ft-deep grave. They had been killed for their money and buried by their daughter Susan and her husband Christopher Edwards, who were both convicted of the  double murders and jailed for le. The heart-rending case is being dramatised in a four-part Sky TV series, with Oscar winner Olivia Colman as Susan Edwards. Nurse Sue, , fears that her home will be a magnet for ghoulish sightseers when Landscapers is screened this year. But she said: “I have no intention of leaving.” She recalled her shock when police, acting on a tip-off, started digging up her back garden in  and told her: “We have found human remains.”  Sue, who moved to the house at Forest Town, Notts, in  with daughter Sophie, , said: “I went to pieces after seeing them taken away in body bags. “I was so upset to think that those two poor old people had been buried in my garden for all that time. “We went away for the weekend and by the time I got home on Monday the police had filled in the hole and removed their tents, so the garden was almost back to normal. “Detectives eventually confirmed that Mr and Mrs Wycherley had been killed in my bedroom.”  Sue recalled seeing the police teams digging around where Sophie had lain a flower bed. “I watched in horried fascination as their snfer dogs focused on that particular patch of garden by the back door, where oddly we’d never been able to grow flowers or plants,” she said. “Also I thought of how my four-year-old nephew used to bury his toy cars in the garden and his five-year-old sister would then have to try to find them. “I was aghast at what they could have found.” The police believe that gun fanatic Christopher Edwards, , shot his ­in-laws at point-blank range with a Second World War . revolver as his we Susan, , looked on.  After burying their victims in the back garden, the evil couple pretended that Patricia, , and Bill, , were alive to steal £, in their names. They kept up the pretence for  years. Using forged documents, they sold the Wycherleys’ house, claimed their £-a-month pensions, took out loans by posing as the dead couple and filched disability benefits. Childless Susan, once a police civilian clerk, replied to letters and cards written by relatives to her parents – signing off as them. She and her husband were both convicted and sentenced in  over the murders.  Even though Sue now knows the full ghastly truth about her House of Horrors, she insists: “I love it here.” She has planted a bush on her patio in memory of the murdered couple and said: “What was done to the Wycherleys was awful and no one deserves to die like that. “I often think about them – but this has never deterred me from living here. It is a lovely house and I like the area.

title: rachael bletchly my criticism meghans
story: NewsopinionRachael Bletchly: My criticism of Meghans behaviour does not make me racist Many people have called the British press coverage of Meghan Markle racist, but not every criticism of the duchess should be seen in this way, writes Rachael BletchlyShareCommentsByRachael Bletchly:,  JAN NewsopinionThe Duke and Duchess of Sussex have caused major controversy in recent weeks " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailFour hundred years agoanyone had pointed at me and shouted “Witch!” the chances of proving my innocence were pretty slim. I’d get hauled up before the Witchfinder General who’d strip me, searching for the third nipple on which I suckled my animal familiar. Any mole or freckle would damn me so then I’d be trussed up and thrown in a river with a rope around my waist. If I floated, I was a witch and they’d burn me If I sank, I was innocent... though probably drowned. Yet there was still a tiny chance they’d haul me out alive, reputation restored. But this week, when called “a racist witch” I realised there was no way to prove I’m not. A racist, I mean. Because I am a white, privileged woman andI criticise or question a woman of colour – whatever the reason – that is blatant, or at the very least unconscious, racism. And, as a white, privileged, woman and tabloid ­journalist I am doubly damned. This has, of course, been prompted by my opinions about the Duke and Duchess of Sussex and the “abdication” crisis. I’ve had a belly-full of this PAIR of petulant, selfish, ­hypocritical whingers and wrote that they can “bugger off to Canada for all I care” as long as we taxpayers don’t have to pay for it. But that was racial abuse, apparently. I was “bullying a black woman and telling her to get back to her own country”. Some people told me I need to check my privilege. That I’m moulded by ingrained, institutional prejudice, working in a racist media in a totally racist country. How can I NOT be a racist  I am shocked, baffled and utterly outraged at the stream of re-parroted rot being spouted about the supposed ­vilication of Meghan by the media.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailPrince Harry has given up a large part of his income and the use of his title to forge a new le for him and his we. At .pm this evening statements from Buckingham Palace and The Queen gave details of the deal struck between the Duke and Duchess of Sussex and the Queen. The victorious central point from Harry and Meghanaposs perspective is that they have been granted permission to step back from their royal duties. They have also been given the green light to spend a majority of their time away from the UK, most likely in Canada. In winning these freedoms however, Harry has had to shed large parts of the royal le he has lived for the past  years. A big change is the way the coupleaposs finances will work. While Harry will still have the multi-million pound inheritance he received from his mother Princess Diana, as well as an undisclosed annual sum from the Duchy of Cornwall, his outgoings will increase signicantly. Not only will they be paying back the £.million of Sovereign Grant that was spent to refurbish Frogmore Cottage , the couple will pay commercial rent on the home when they are abroad. As well as relieving himself of a fair chunk of his fortune, Harry will no longer be able to use the His Royal Highness title that has adjourned him since he was a young boy. Although he will remain a Duke, he will be HRH in name only.  Another key dference for Harry are the patronages that he will be keeping. Both he and Meghan will retain their personal patronages of charities, but the Prince will lose his official association to the military organisations he currently represents. From the Spring he will no longer be a patron of the Royal Marines, the Royal Naval Commandaposs Small Ships and Diving nor the Royal Air Force Honington.  The couple will also no longer go on royal tours. Most recently they went together to South Africa, Malawi, Angola and Botswana. Harry will also spend a lot more time away from his core group of friends and his family when he sets up shop in North America.While the changes announced today signal the start of a new chapter for the royal family, the Queen suggested her affections were unlikely to waver. She said: Following many months of conversations and more recent discussions, I am pleased that together we have found a constructive and supportive way forward for my grandson and his family, The Queen wrote in a statement released at .pm on Saturday.

title: top tips fitter healthier you
story: NewsTop tips for a fitter and healthier you - without a costly gym membershipFrom ten-minute NHS workouts, to YouTube tutorials and household chores, here are some crafty ideas for getting your health on track without going to the gymShareCommentsByHelen Whitehouse:,  JAN NewsSwimming is a gentle activity which uses all of your muscles " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe gym is an ­intimidating place for a lot of us – but paying to join one is not the only fitness option. Statistics show that  per cent of women feel apprehensive about working out in public ­– because of what other people might think. But there’s no need to let your gym fear stop you making healthy habits. Research has shown that exercise can combat mild to ­moderate depression, improve body composition, decrease stress and manage a multitude of blood markers, such as ­cholesterol and AC. It will also reduce your risk of falls, lessen pain and allow you to remain active throughout your le. Here we have put together some top tips on how to get fitter without a costly gym membership.  Use your phone For a gentle ­introduction to exercise, a tracking app such as MyFitnessPal could help. You can set it up with a step target and then, as you walk around, it counts your steps. It is satisfying to see how many calories you burn. And as your fitness levels go up, you can ­increase your step target. Another app, Freeletics, has workouts that require no ­equipment, oryou fancy ­something more gentle, Yoga Wake Up guides you through ­meditations and yoga exercises. The NHS-approved Couch to K podcast is also free to ­download. It guides you through runs, increasing in speed and distance up to km. Dive into the pool As exercises go, you can’t beat a gentle swim to start off your ­fitness regime. It gets your heart rate and ­fitness levels up, but at the same time is low impact, so you are less likely to get injured or pull muscles. Swimming helps to tone, build strength and keeps your heart healthy. As you use so much of your body, it’s very effective at burning calories for weight-loss too. Most pools or leisure ­centres have adult only or ladies only swimming ­sessions so you can feel more comfortable. Clean your house It is a task many of us want to avoid – but by energetically cleaning the house you will ­improve fitness levels.According to experts, ­cleaning can burn  cals per hour. Hoovering, mopping, ­dusting the kitchen cabinets and hauling shopping in from the carall count towards improving your fitness, evenit is only in a small way. And that is far better than no exercise at all.Try ten-minute workouts The NHS has a handy guide on a range of ten-minute workouts you can do from the comfort of your own home. They have put together six workouts to do once a day, each focussing on a dferent area of the body. All of are free of charge, as well as equipment-free. They are available online at nhs.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA police chief has called for an urgent meeting with the commander of an RAF base after incidents of two more cars driving on the wrong side of the road emerged. Footage reported to Northamptonshire Police on Saturday and shows a blue BMW having to brake very sharply on a country road close to RAF Croughton where Mr Dunn was killed. And a separate incident last October involving a driver crashing into a police car near the RAF base where Harry Dunn was killed has prompted the Northamptonshire Police Chief Constable to intervene. The latest footage has now prompted police discussions at the highest level in light of Harry Dunnaposs death. In a statement, the chief constable said: I do not underestimate how much of a concerning incident this was and how much worse it could have been, especially considering the circumstances in which -year-old Harry Dunn tragically died.This is compounded by the fact that yesterday, myself and Police, Fire and Crime Commissioner Stephen Mold were made aware of another incident in Northampton in which a police vehicle was struck in early October by a vehicle also driving on the wrong side of the road. Thankfully there were no injuries. I want to be absolutely clear on the fact that these incidents just cannot keep happening. We know all too well in the case of young Harry just how devastating they can be. Therefore the PFCC and I have requested an urgent meeting with the base commander at RAF Croughton to discuss safety on the roads around the base and I expect this meeting to take place next week. The RAF base became the focus of an international controversy after Mr Dunn died in a head-on collision with a car yards away on August  last year. Harry Dunn, , died after being hit by a car allegedly driven by Anne Sacoolas, who left the country for the US claiming diplomatic immunity. The US State Department said a UK extradition request for Mrs Sacoolas was highly inappropriate and would be an abuse. Mr Dunn was driving a motorcycle outside the RAF base Croughton where Mrs Sacoolasapos husband Jonathan worked as an intelligence officer. Boris Johnson has said the chances of Mrs Sacoolas being extradited to the UK are very low. Before reports of the latest incident surfaced, Business Secretary Andrea Leadsom, the constituency MP for Mr Dunnaposs family, wrote to the commander of the base to ask for an invitation to visit. Mr Dunnaposs mother Charlotte Charles and father Tim Dunn are looking for assurances that safety measures are in place to make sure there are no similar incidents in the future.  Confirming the force had been given the footage, a spokesman said: We can confirm we have received a report of this incident. It falls in the Thames Valley area, but the Chief Constablehas seen the footage. The incident is currently being discussed at the highest level in light of the ongoing investigation in Northamptonshire. Dunn family spokesman Radd Seiger said: Seeing this footage has sent shivers down my spine and made me feel sick. No harm done on this occasion fortunately but that is not the point. I have been urging everyone in authority to take the matter seriously, not only in terms of safety and how we can improve it in relation to helping American drivers adjust to the dferent side of the road, but also ensuring that no one who breaks the law coming off the base is allowed to hop on the next plane home and evade justice as Anne Sacoolas did. Enough is enough. This near miss brings both issues sharply into focus and I now call on the UK Government to take immediate action to ensure the safety of their citizens living in and around these bases but also to make sure that never again will a so-called aposdiplomatapos be allowed to evade justice.

story: NewsUK weather forecast: Met Office warns highest pressure in  years will make ears popThe UK is in line for record breaking atmospheric pressure tomorrow, when the hectopascal gauge will rise to its highest point in close to thirty years, the Met Office has saidShareCommentsByMilo Boyd:,  JAN NewsAn unusual amount of ear popping is due to take place in the UK tomorrow " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Met Office has warned that ears could pop tomorrow when Britain experiences the highest atmospheric pressure in decades. Contrasting temperatures across the US and a south moving jet stream has pushed a pocket of unusually high pressure towards the UK. Tomorrow evening running through into Monday the gauges will likely be pushed above , hectopascals. If it does it will have beaten the most recent record of . measured in , while also nearing the  high.The effect of the high pressure on the ground will be felt in the ears and will lead to a period of pleasant, settled weather . Alex Burkhill, a meteorologist with the Met Office , said: Itaposs going to bring lots of fine settled weather and ears might pop a bit more than otherwise.It will be largely fine and dry. The high pressure has been here today, which is why it was so sunny and lovely. That will stick around for the rest of the week. Sunday night into Monday is the high point when it comes to the pressure. Mr Burkhill went on to emphasise just how remarkable tomorrowaposs weather system is likely to be.  We have high pressure which means stabled and settled, but how high is the remarkable bit, he said. Itaposs likely we could get atmospheric pressure of around  hPa. We have only had figures that high around ten times in the last hundreds of so year. The highest was ,.hPA. That was  January, , in Aberdeen.  The high point is probably going to be towards the south west this time. The good weather experienced by large parts of Britain today has the high pressure to thank. This will continue tomorrow when the entire south side of the country will enjoy clear blue skies and plenty of sun.

title: waxwork collector plans sell head
story: NewsWaxwork collector plans to sell the head of Beatles legend George HarrisonEXCLUSIVE: Colin Hill bought the old Madame Tussauds piece for £ and keeps it in a cabinet with replicas heads of Britney Spears, Winston Churchill and Princess DianaShareCommentsByPhil Cardy:,  JAN NewsColin Hill collects waxworks and plans to sell his replica head of George Harrison " to FREE daily email alerts from Mirror - Royal FamilySubscribeWe will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. The owner of a scary collection of waxwork heads is selling off the bonce of Beatles guitar legend George Harrison. Colin Hill bought it for less than £ five years ago and keeps it in a cabinet along with the heads of Britney Spears, Winston Churchill and a barely recognisable Princess Diana. And the Fab Four fan hopes to make thousandshis sale plan can Come Together. Retired hospital worker Colin, , waxes lyrical about his collection. He says: “At the auction they also had Ringo’s head but I was outbid for that. I don’t know what happened to Paul and John’s heads. “It would have been nice to get both of them. They were from Madame Tussauds and had been left in a storeroom.“I’ve got dealers interested in Harrison. I obtained a copy of a Madame Tussauds photo showing the head displayed with the other Beatles. “A card says ‘rare waxwork of the Beatles in Sgt. Pepper period’. It looks like it’s from around that time. It would be interesting to know what it’s worth, especially as it’s been ‘lost’ for all these years.” In  a full set of Beatles wax heads in Sgt. Pepper mode sold for £,. Sunday Mirror antiques expert Jamie Breese said it is dficult to put a value on the Harrison head. He said: “This is an unusual piece and is going to be of interest. In terms of value, this may be unique so is particularly tricky when it comes to appraising. It is most likely a case of letting the market decide the value.” The Beatles were the first band to appear in Madame Tussauds’ London museum, in .
